publisher: Hogarth Press and Institute of Psychoanalysis
title: Quotations from Freud have been taken from the two following editions of his work: SE The Standard Edition of the Complete Psychological Works of Sigmund Freud (1953–74

note: Less complete, but more easily available. When a work not included in the Penguin Freud Library is referred to in the text, the page reference is to the Standard Edition.
See particularly Breuer’s case of Anna O., who coined the phrase ‘talking cure’, and Freud’s cases of Emmy von N. and Elizabeth von R.
title: SE 2; PFL 3. These fascinating case studies are an excellent starting point for understanding the origins of psychoanalysis
The Interpretation of Dreams (1900
answer the question,‘What does woman want?’ It has been a taking-off point for many important feminist analyses – see Bernheimer and Kahane
Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality (1905

Along with The Interpretation of Dreams this is probably Freud’s most important and ground-breaking work. He revised it continuously over his lifetime. It is the main place to go for his theories of the stages of sexual development and the perversions
Civilized Sexual Morality and Modern Nervous Illness
This is Freud’s earliest discussion of the conflict between civilization and instinctual life which becomes central to his theories in works such as Civilization and its Discontents

container-title: His readings of the Rat Man’s obsessive ideas are stark and original
title: Notes upon a Case of Obsessional Neurosis (Rat Man
Of Freud’s major case histories, this is undoubtedly his most successful

container-title: These were given as a series of lectures by Freud in America in

title: This slim collection is still the best very short introduction to Freud’s major ideas that you can find
Leonardo Da Vinci and a Memory of his Childhood
SE
to look for the strengths and weaknesses of Freud’s theorising of homosexuality
This is one of Freud’s oddest and most compulsive works. It contains his ideas about the repetition compulsion and the death drive
It has been a key text for further post-structuralist readings of Freud
Group Psychology and the Analysis of the Ego

In this fascinating article Freud explores questions about the relationship between crowd behaviour and individual psychology. It’s good to read this along with Totem and Taboo and Civilization and Its Discontents

container-title: In it Freud theorises his concept of the bodily ego
title: The Ego and The Id
This one sounds like it’s just what you want to explain Freud’s basic concepts, but it is in fact very dense and difficult

note: If you want Freud’s life story see Jones (1953–7) or Gay (1989) below.
title: An Autobiographical Study

Although this contains some interesting autobiographical touches, it is much more the story of psychoanalysis the institution than of Freud the person. It gives a more balanced perspective than ‘On the History of the Psychoanalytic Movement’
London:Virago. This dauntingly large volume is good for background on Freud’s women patients, colleagues and relations
Cambridge: Icon Books Ltd. This comic-book version of Freud’s ideas is an entertaining and painless way to get the basics with illustrations

note: including Jacqueline Rose, Neil Hertz and Jane Gallop.
title: In Dora’s Case: Freud-Hysteria-Feminism, London:Virago. This collection is a psychoanalytic feminist classic. It contains extremely helpful articles on ‘Dora’ by many important psychoanalytic critics
The Memory Wars: Freud’s Legacy in Dispute

New York: New York Review of Books. Crews was a rabidly enthusiastic psychoanalytic critic who later renounced psychoanalysis with great vigour. This collection includes hypercritical articles about Freud he wrote for the New York Review of Books and a selection of the letters they published in response
Dispatches from the Freud Wars: Psychoanalysis and its Passions (1997
Forrester’s book is one of the best places to turn to for cogent analyses of the backlash against Freud from a psychoanalytic sympathiser
Freud:A Life for our Time (1989

This is a compulsively readable biography of Freud. However, if you’re looking for critical distance go elsewhere. Gay is almost as admiring of Freud as Freud’s devoted follower Ernest Jones who wrote the first worshipful biography of the Great Man
Jones’s uncritical attitude to Freud can be exasperating at times but this is still a fascinating biography of a fascinating mind, written by someone who was on the scene at the time
The Language of Psychoanalysis

This is by far the best dictionary of psychoanalytic terms available, but it is also much more than that. Although nearly twenty years old it still contains the smartest and most accurate explanations of Freud’s terminology
New Haven: Yale University Press. A readable, straightforward exploration of the power of Freud’s rhetoric

collection-title: This is a good recent collection of essays on The Interpretation of
title: Sigmund Freud’s The Interpretation of Dreams: New Interdisciplinary Essays (1999
A collection that leans towards the philosophical questions that Freud’s work provokes
The Mind of the Moralist
Chicago: University of Chicago Press. Rieff’s work is invaluable as a wonderful, early thinking-through of the moral and ethical questions that analysis raises
Oxford: Oxford University Press. A short, engagingly written, but very selective, lay-person’s guide to Freud
Unbeatable for accuracy and sophistication, this advanced guide to Freud’s ideas and stages of his thought is probably not for beginners
The Anxiety of Influence: A Theory of Poetry (1973

Bloom applies Freud’s Oedipal theory to poets, arguing that strong poets must metaphorically kill off their poetic forefathers in order to carve a place for themselves in the canon of tradition. Very influential when it was first written; it has since been criticised from several angles including feminist theory

note: This is probably the most accurate and well-written explication of Lacan available.

title: Between Feminism and Psychoanalysis
London and New York: Routledge. This is a somewhat dated, but still cogent, collection of articles exploring the ways in which French feminist theory has used and critiqued psychoanalysis

container-title: book contains excellent analyses of a number of English and European novels
title: Reading for the Plot: Design and Intention in Narrative
New York:Vintage
Freud and the Scene of Writing
Derrida responds to Freud’s short article, ‘The Mystic Writing Pad’. This is a very difficult piece but key for establishing the deconstructive reading of Freud
The Postcard: From Socrates to Freud and Beyond
Continuing in Derrida’s difficult style, it contains important articles about Lacan and Beyond the Pleasure Principle
Femmes Fatales: Feminism, Film Theory, Psychoanalysis
London, Routledge. Doane’s work on film theory is sharp and provocative. A good place to look for skillful psychoanalytic readings of individual films
Psychoanalytic Literary Criticism

This is the best recent collection of articles on psychoanalysis and literature. Ellman’s introduction is invaluable, and Cynthia Chase’s article ‘Oedipal Textuality: Reading Freud’s Reading of Oedipus’ is a classic reading of Sophocles with Freud
Turning the Screw of Interpretation’

Felman’s tour-de-force Lacanian reading of Henry James’s uncanny tale ‘The Turn of the Screw’ brilliantly describes the relationship between literature and transference. It has dated, however, in that its reliance on a certain kind of deconstructive rhetoric that flourished in the 1970s now appears somewhat overblown and decontextualised. The close readings are nonetheless masterly
The Daughter’s Seduction: Feminism and Psychoanalysis
Ithaca: Cornell University Press. An early sharp feminist critique of Freud. Gallop’s provocative style is always fun to read, if often contentious. One of her specialties is deflating the phallus
Jacques Lacan: A Feminist Introduction
London: Routledge. Useful as an overview of the often vexed relationship between feminism and Lacanian psychoanalysis
Desire in Language: A Semiotic Approach to Literature and Art (1980
Powers of Horror: An Essay on Abjection

note: Definitely not for beginners. Go to Moi (1985) first if it’s all too frightening.
title: Kristeva’s combination of psychoanalysis and French feminist critiques of language is still challenging to read, and her analyses of specific works of literature are often compelling. Her more recent work flounders in some dodgy political waters, but her early books, especially Powers of Horror and Black Sun create a fascinating poetics of the feminine

container-title: Peter Brooks’s useful article ‘The Idea of a Psychoanalytic Literary Criticism’, and Arnold I. Davidson’s fantastic Foucauldian reading of Freud’s Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality
title: The Trial(s) of Psychoanalysis (1988
This excellent collection contains Stanley Fish’s entertaining and brutal, yet thought-provoking, attack on Freud’s rhetoric ‘Withholding the Missing Portion’
New York: Pantheon. Mitchell’s important book began the reclaiming of psychoanalysis for feminism in England
Lacan Feminine Sexuality: Jacques Lacan and the École freudienne (1985
Mitchell’s and Rose’s separate introductions to this collection of writings of Lacan on women are invaluable for charting the relationship between Freud’s and Lacan’s ideas about sexuality
Sexual/Textual Politics: Feminist Literary Theory (1985

Although this book is now fifteen years old and lags far behind in terms of recent developments in feminism, it is still a good starting point for understanding the arguments between Anglo-American and French feminism, and how psychoanalysis fits into those debates
Visual and Other Pleasures (1989
Mulvey’s influential 1975 article ‘Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema’, included in this collection, began a new discussion about the ‘gaze’ and sexual difference in film theory

Phillips’s short articles on psychoanalysis are compulsively readable and extremely entertaining. A practising analyst himself, his work is committed to making complicated analytic ideas accessible and connected to real life

London:Verso. This collection of Rose’s articles contains difficult but excellent explanations of the importance of Lacan to feminism and to theories of the visual, as well as interesting feminist psychoanalytic readings of George Eliot and Hamlet
London:Virago. A brilliant example of how psychoanalytic reading can yield rich literary results in the case of a single author

New York: Penguin. Showalter’s work on nineteenth-century women and madness seems a bit dated now, but it is still a useful starting point for thinking about the cultural context from which Freud’s ideas about women emerge

container-title: It contains extracts from several classic essays, including Shoshona Felman’s article on Henry James, ‘Turning the Screw of Interpretation’, and Peter Brooks’s ‘Freud’s Masterplot’
note: Be aware of the limitations of extracted essays however.
title: Psychoanalytic Criticism: A Reader (1996

This is a useful collection which juxtaposes psychoanalytic articles of general interest with specific psychoanalytic readings of texts such as Virginia Woolf’s Mrs Dalloway and Toni Morrison’s Beloved

container-title: www.plaza.interport.net/nyspan/ An index of libraries, museums and bibliographical material on Freud. www.lcweb.loc.gov/exhibits/freud/ The Library of Congress ‘Conflict and Culture’ exhibit on Freud. www.freud.org.uk The site of the Freud Museum in London
title: Psychoanalytic Criticism: Theory in Practice (1984
Wright’s book is densely written, but helpful for tracing the history of psychoanalytic criticism after Freud but before the current climate
